text:
I want to share some footage
from a recent project of ours, the DARPA Subterranean Challenge
that Marco just referred to.

The goal of the challenge was
to develop robotic teams that could explore natural and
built underground environments,

such as tunnels, caves,
mines, urban settings, like, subway systems in order to
find objects of interest,

known as artifacts
in the challenge, and build maps of
the environment. Implicitly, this was a
multi-robot coordination

challenge, and, also, a
human robot interaction one as a supplementary component. I'll talk a little
bit about that.

And the challenge
started in 2018, when we were selected
for funding as part of the competition by DARPA.

And we had about a
year to go from having no coordination between
the PI team and our groups.

Research groups were four of us. And having to spin
up essentially a fully staffed $1.5
million a year operation

to serve the project. Very few PhD students
were interested. I'm sure some of you can
imagine why that would be.

We had a core group of students
who were very intrigued by the challenge, though. And the competition made
up the bulk of their PhDs,

as they were
completing the project. There were three
competition deployments. Originally, scheduled
to be four, but because

of COVID, only three. The first was in a limestone
mine in Pittsburgh. The second one was in an
abandoned nuclear power plant

outside of Olympia, Washington. And the final event was in an
underground constructed course incorporating elements of
various different types

is, essentially, an enormous
underground cave and tunnel system. So this is just some
footage, as people

are trying to get
themselves situated and what's going on
with this project. So the final course,
as I was mentioning,

was quite challenging. The scale of the
course was enormous for many robotic deployments,
with large caves augmented

into the constructed course and
narrow caverns with challenging terrain elements strewn about by
DARPA, such as these rails here,

which were, basically,
meant to stop any tracked or
wheeled robots that were trying to go over them. And on the left,
an enormous cave

that had to be explored
in its entirety of volume, because they could have put an
artifact basically anywhere.

And to live up to their
tagline of DARPA Hard, it's a term that's frequently
used by DARPA projects,

the competition included a
fully constructed subway system, including a ticketing
station platform, subway rails, tunnel about 100
meters in length inside of it.

Really, a fun course to have to
walk through at the end of it. As I mentioned, there was an
HRI, human-robot interaction

component of this project. Where did that live? It was with this single
human supervisor here wearing

an orange helmet. That was the only
individual that was on the team who
could, actually,

interact with the
robots, once they were past the starting gate. And the interface here of how
the supervisor would interact

with the robots
was up to them was how the interface
would, actually, communicate with the robots.

So this was really
our project to build from the ground up
interfacing with DARPA systems

and how we go into the mine. We had 15 minutes to
set up the system. It was supposed to simulate what
was like a real-world disaster

scenar-- or disaster response scenario. And this person, with
all of what you saw here,

was everything that was
possible after that 15 minutes. So here, I show a few photos
from the final event, just

to give you more
montage background here. It consisted of constant
testing at the event.

Team meetings, a
lot of discussion with other teams, because
this was a group of us plus seven other teams that were
there from all over the world

competing. And at the conclusion
of the competition, our team finished
third place globally.

And it's the top
American led team eking out a win over
teams led by JPL and CMU, but placing behind
teams that were

from an international
constituency Norwegian Technical, ETH Zurich,
and the Australian CSIRO.

So we were able to
walk through the course afterwards and observe,
like I mentioned, what we had missed in the
enormity of this built structure

that DARPA had. So that's that one
little vent right there, which was one of the artifacts
that we were looking for.

And that was after the
competition was over. We could do this
quick walk through. And, like I mentioned,
we scored third place,

which meant that we took home
$500,000, which was meant to-- was had been used to support our
research groups continuously.

So with that introduction aside,
I want to talk a little bit more about what our team's
solution was, how it evolved

over time, why we had an eye
for radar-based perception in this challenge, and maybe
some next steps on where we

would take this going forward. So first, I want
to say, our team

was fairly large for
most research projects. One might imagine it
to be quite large. And by that, I mean,
this is a group

of almost entirely PhD students
with a few undergraduates, broken up into their
different spheres of influence

in the project. As you can see, we had a
team that was specifically focused on platforms.

We had another team
that was specifically focused on building out all the
autonomy components, including perception components, and
planning, and decision making.

We, actually, had to set
up our own comms system, as I mentioned, inside the
caves that were, basically,

RF absorbing. So we had a dedicated
communications team for that. And we had a
management team, which

I'll talk about a little
bit, not just PIs, but also some graduate
students that we elevated

to the position of
project engineer to provide extra management. So today, I'm going
to focus mostly on platforms and autonomy.

And I won't be able to talk
about our comms solution. It was very interesting. And if you're interested
more of how that was,

we, actually, have a field
robotics journal paper that just came out, which
you can read more about how

that worked. In case you're wondering why I
highlighted some students names, those are the students
in my research group.

Those names that are in red. So let's jump into
platforms to talk about our evolution of platform
decisions, which, I think,

is a nice microcosm for
how these challenges work, and, in some sense,
how we might think

about deploying robotic
solutions into the wild. So when one ends up with a
research project like this, one,

typically, is faced with a
decision about how to start and what is the easiest
thing to start with.

Mostly, the platforms you
have sitting around the lab. Am I right? So if that's the case,
then you look around.

And you say, well,
we have some Huskies. And, previously, my work has
done some research in this one eighth scale RC car world.

And so these two platforms were
meant for very different tasks. On the right-hand
side, this Parkour car.

We idealized as a robot
with a mobile comm relay. So that would be that it
would just be sending signals

back and forth between
these Huskies, which were the ones that
were essentially doing all of the object
detection or artifact

identification, as well as
high definition mapping. So the Huskies is what
I'm going to focus on

in this conversation. Our tunnel configuration, which
was the first configuration we deployed, featured
a similar sensor post

to what we, actually, ended up
with in the final competition. It had some evolution on it. And I'll focus on
that in a little bit.

But it was outfitted with an
OS1-64 channel LiDAR right on top, as you'll probably see
in almost all robot designs.

The robot LiDAR is,
typically, the highest sensor in the platform. And Intel RealSense D435 array,
so you can see four D435s.

Two facing forward. Two facing obliquely
to the side. And what is not pictured here,
though, is a drip shielding.

So just when you thought
Pittsburgh weather was bad enough, it,
actually, rains and caves there, which we found out,
when we deployed to Pittsburgh.

So there was rain
everywhere, even underground. It's horrible. So the challenges we saw
from this particular setup

were that, for instance, on the
right-hand side, this Parkour car, it's an Ackerman
steering vehicle. If you don't know
what that means,

it's basically that it
has to back up in order to make certain types of
turns, three-point turns,

five-point turns. This creates an enormous
challenge for planning. But, also, is not great
for narrow corridors.

I don't even know
what we were thinking when we thought we
would feel this thing, because the narrow corridor
has made it so you, basically,

must be correct in how you're
aiming against the walls. Not easy.

And so we thought that
this thing would give us a bunch of speed improvements.

But, in fact, the
speed that the car gave was never realized,
because a single false move would be catastrophic.

So we, basically, just
crawled it forward. In fact, nobody moved
very quickly at tunnel.

And I would argue, no one
really moved fast anywhere, which brings me to one
of the conclusions,

I think, I want to
bring out firsthand, which is that
reliability is extremely

important in almost all robotic
deployments in the wild. And if speed is part
of your sales pitch

or what you're trying
to do in your team, then you're going to have a
really hard time with that, because speed increases
the lack of reliability

that any one of your other
components might have in it. In fact, this
lesson was, I think,

learned gradually by all of
us throughout the program. Nobody, actually, moved fast
by the end of the program.

Everything was moving, at
most, one meter a second. And so that's a little
bit of one of those things

that I want to get to the
conclusion about, where I think things could
go looking forward.

Next, I'm going
to just say, what was our urban configuration? This is the next
competition event.

So on the top right, I show this
little graph, where it's tunnel was the first event.

Urban was the next event. So urban is the next
evolution of our systems. And we did pretty
well at tunnel.

We, actually, placed, I think,
we tied for third or something. We did fairly well.

And we thought, OK, if we have
a good standard or foundation, we're going to expand on that.

So we decided to ditch
the-- first of all, ditch the fixed multi-RealSense
camera configuration

used for artifact detection. And instead, what
we decided to do is put a single RealSense
on a pan-tilt unit.

So that it could look around. One of the things
we saw was that this multi-RealSense
configuration did

a couple of different things. One of them is that if you
have a bunch of USB vision cameras hooked up with USB 3
to a computer, very frequently,

you end up with
bandwidth issues. If one USB camera falls off
because of a bandwidth issue,

it, actually, can take down the
entire USB controller, which means you no longer
have any vision,

which would have meant
that our platforms are useless in the cave. So that was not acceptable. We decided to go
to one RealSense.

But, obviously, one
RealSense can only look in a very
narrow field of view. So we thought, why not
put it on a pan-tilt?
That was a terrible idea. And I'll get to why. So we had that configuration.

We also added a few
different drivetrains here. We said we're going to replicate
what we did with the Husky. And put it on these
track vehicles.

Justification for
that, well, if we're going into urban environments,
we have to go upstairs. And wheeled vehicles
can't easily go upstairs.

Boston Dynamics hadn't begun
selling their Spot robot at the time. If you wanted some
quadruped, you would have had to
build it yourself.

And if you do it just right,
then these tracked vehicles or tracked vehicles
plus some flippers

can, actually, go upstairs. So we thought, that's going
to solve the stair problem. We complemented
it with, actually,

a smaller vehicle
called the LT2. Also, had the pan-tilt
configuration. Basically, just a smaller
version of the tracked vehicle.

And we added a UAV
on, just because we thought we had more time and
not enough difficulty already.

So all together, we felt that
this simplified our solution. We eliminated some
of our RealSenses.

We decided to replicate
the Husky platform onto the tracked
vehicle platform.

Who thinks that this looks
like it's simplifying? I'm sure nobody in this room.

So in reality,
this was, actually, like a disaster at urban. And I want to focus in on why.

So even though we had removed,
made some substitutions, we, for instance, decided, OK,
we're going to use a pan-tilt,

there were a lot of challenges
with this particular type of fleet loadout. So tracked vehicles required
completely different terrain

classification systems
that would be built around, basically, what their new
high center position would be.

They would high
center everywhere. They, actually, just got
stuck on even small steps.

When I mean high
centering, that means you can't move after it,
because you have some contact condition that's no longer
satisfied for your drivetrain.

The pan-tilt unit that we had,
because it was using a pan-tilt, it would, actually,
have encoders in it

to determine where it was
looking at any given time. Encoder failures would
result in our not

knowing what we were
looking at, even if we had a camera that
was giving us imagery. So we couldn't project
where these artifacts were

into the frame of
reference of the robot, because you had these
encoder failures. So what did we do?

We did what many engineers
make the mistake of, replacing a multi-point
of failure system with a single point of failure
one, which, actually, doesn't

really help you. Because if you have a
single point of failure hit, then, essentially, you
have decided-- then

your system no longer works. The UAV, actually,
worked pretty well, but needed twice as
long as we had given it

for development time. So we ended up scrapping
it for the deployment. Just a bunch of different
issues associated with that.

So, basically, the summation
of this was at urban, we tried with the three
self-funded teams in place last

with respect to all
the DARPA-funded teams. And this was an absolute
low point of our morale.

And what would you have it? COVID happened 1 and
1/2 months later. So we couldn't even meet to
work on the platform to debrief.

Some of us talked about
pulling out of the competition. What are we going to do? We all really took a step back
and started having just a bunch

of-- as we all did
during that time-- Zoom meetings to figure
out what was our next step. How are we going to respond
to this setback at urban?

So I think COVID was
a real reset for us. And some of my
conversations today have focused on identifying
crises for what they are.

I think the pandemic really
changed how we did work, both from this perspective,
but also graduate school,

in general. I think many of us can
understand what I mean by that. And the team decided to have
two graduate students instead as

a response to our
failure at urban. Take on what I mentioned
as project engineer responsibilities or leadership
at par, if not, above the PIs

on the project. And there were a lot
of reasons for that. But I would say, I would
attribute our final win at--

or our win at final to them. I think they probably
worked like 80-hour weeks. But, also, they were
very willing to tell us

when something
was not reasonable or when people had
questions that they weren't willing to raise to us.

But I'll talk about that in
just another slide in a sec. Our final loadout just to talk
about what you see on this slide

is this. So we ended up with a clear
path Husky, same as before, tried and true. You'll notice that we don't
have any tracked vehicles,

because tracked
vehicles, as I mentioned, are super challenging in a
terrain categorization setting.

The compute stack was
left largely unchanged. A few sensors were removed. So we, actually, removed
flash LiDAR from our setting.

And what we did was we
replaced all of our cameras with gigabit ethernet cameras.

And we decided to put four
of them back on there. Gigabit ethernet is amazing. If you've never worked
with GigE Vision before,

I strongly recommend it. What happens when you drop
a frame in GigE, nothing. You just don't get the frame.

The next frame will come within
the next one 30th of a second. It's awesome. We had completely reworked our
beacon deployment mechanism,

as well as, the infrastructure
supporting the networking. Six beacons per Husky rather
than like the 24 you saw before.

We realized we didn't
need that many. And we purchased
two spot platforms. They, finally, went on sale.

And we were able
to get two of them. And so what did this give us? Well, it supported our not
having the tracked vehicle

anymore, because, now,
we could go upstairs. And Boston Dynamics
engineered the hell out of this stair climbing
capability on the spot.

The black box
attached to this spot here is, actually, almost the
same as what's inside the Husky,

but with a few years extra
of development of hardware. That's what we were able
to miniaturize it down to.

And we even were able to
put a small GPU inside of it for artifact detection on
computer vision, which was,

again, the purpose
of the challenge. And the use of the
Spot allowed us to traverse more tortuous
terrain travel, twice

as fast as the Huskies
or any other platform we had seen before. Travel up and down stairs. It was really a
true game changer.

I think that many
people realized after urban, when
one team successfully fielded a Spot, the JPL
team, who had somehow

gotten their hands on the Spot
earlier than anybody else, that quadrupeds were the
solution to this challenge.

It might seem like
wheeled vehicles would be. But, in fact, even with
really bad terrain,

this Spot could be
able to handle it. So this was just a couple
of takeaways I think.

The conclusions from this was
that I think some features are

conditioned on
deep design choices is not really an obvious
finding or conclusion.

So one of these issues was that
we couldn't deploy a UAV off of the Husky.

And the reason for that
was that every time we wanted to do mapping
and localization, that

would have to
start from the gate and have to be surveyed
in to the gate. There was no way to
serialize the state

of any one of our
robots and then transmit that to another robot. And that was, actually,
a design choice that was necessitated by using ROS.

And I think that there's a
lot of very interesting issues here, like a feature
that we wanted

had been conditioned on
a capability or a design decision that was made
very early in our project.

So we don't know what
those are years later. But that's something that is a
risk to all ongoing projects,

when you think about, maybe,
we can add this functionality somewhere later on. So, also, is that
terrain traverse ability

is a keystone capability. You need to be able to go
over any types of terrain.

And the larger the window or the
aperture of the type of terrain you can go over, the more
likely you are to be successful.

That remains to be a challenge
today, I would argue. And unless you have a very
intertwined design of your robot

platform with the
control mechanisms that are underlying it, you can,
essentially, fail in this place.

And then have a
catastrophic event, which is why
autonomy is, I think,

one of the harder problems
still condition on that. So speaking of sensors, I
want to talk a little bit

about our sensor head. Every team came up with
some different type of perfect design sensor head.

And yet, all of
them ended up being very similar to this one, which
was three GigE cameras, maybe,

four GigE cameras, and an
ouster or some other kind of automotive grade LiDAR, and
then some illumination in order

to look around and
have those cameras, actually, be able to
look at something. In this case, we also
added a flash LiDAR

for terrain classification
capabilities. But we could have
conceivably done that with our
automotive-grade LiDAR.

We used an IMU,
Parker IMU GX515. Many of you have
probably used it before.

And, actually, I need to
credit CSIRO's Matt Hudson with the idea of
using GigE cameras

as the solution to USB vision. I think that was a really-- that was one of those
cross germination

of ideas that happened, because
we were all in the same area. So that's all for platforms. I think that there's a lot more
that I could go into on that.

But for sake of time, let's
talk about mission management, this human robot
interaction component, where I think there still
exists a big challenge for us.

The mission was managed by
a single human supervisor, as I mentioned before. I think we really lucked out
to have an active air force

colonel on our team was
flying fighter jets.

Actually, somebody
who had had to work under stress in many
different systems and signals that they would
have to be prioritizing between.

So that PhD student
was Dan Riley. He earned his PhD last
year with Eric Frew.

He was our sole human supervisor
and took charge of tasks from managing artifact
reporting to DARPA,

to redirecting robots,
even directly teleoperating the robots with those gamepads
that I had shown previously.

You'll see here the orange
areas in the status bar is during the final
event run, where Dan had to directly
interface with the robot

in order to do
something, override the autonomy in most cases. For those in the know, I
want to show these statistics

in a meaningful way. What does it mean to do autonomy
in these kinds of environments? Typically, we look at what
the percentage in green

is, which is how
frequently somebody had-- our system in perfect
operation, someone

could do nothing, and
just watch it evolve. That was 52% of the time. And the mean time in green
or the number of minutes

that would go by, where a
robot with a full system would need no interaction
was 3.5 minutes.

So that means that, on
average, 3.5 minutes would go by without any event occurring.

And why are these
statistics important? Why do I focus on these? It's because if you have
too frequent of interactions

or this mean time in
green is too short, let's say, one
minute, that means that, on average, the
human supervisor will

have to, actually,
interface with the system in order to fix it every
minute, which means, they either solve the
problem in a minute,

or they have a consistently
increasing backlog of problems that they have to deal with. Many of our co-competitors
had that issue,

where they would say,
the human supervisor is going to do more-- take
more responsibilities. I'll just try to put
that into context.

That was about nine
minutes per robot, which means that
for each robot, you could let it run
for nine minutes

without there being an issue,
which I think is a pretty good, actually,
really good compared

to some of the other
settings that I've seen for field robotics. And this is just
one quick overview.

And this is
explained, I suppose, in better detail in
our journal paper. But where did we
explore and not explore?

We, actually, didn't
explore a lot. So only the deep shaded
places in this map are the places, where
we, actually, went.

And you can see that
that's not the entire map. In fact, we missed this entire
unexplored cave in the back

that I had shown the
picture of before. And yet, we still scored third. Maybe, that's a
lesson to take away.

But let's talk about
that in a second. So to close this out, I want
to just give some, I think,

my pieces of advice
for people that are thinking robots are the future. Let's go ahead and try deploying
these out in the real world.

I think that there's a
multifaceted and delicate balance between validating
and practicing and developing.

And by that, I mean, it's not
a simple trade-off for time. It's not every
minute that you're doing testing or some practice
that you're not developing.

There's two separate ways
that you can spend your time. How should you spend it? It's, actually, that what
I mean by delicate balance,

it's that for every
minute that you're doing some validation
of a system, you're paying into
a pocket of time.

You're going to have
to also pay again in order to validate the new
system, if you innovate on it.

By that, I mean, you will
end up with this system that looks like a NASA launch.

It's, essentially, every
system that is flight approved is the one that we're
going to go with. And if you want to go and
do something different

than a previously
flown component, then you're going to have
to do n hours of testing

on it, where n is equal
to the number of hours that have already gone into
the previous component. It's difficult to do.

So it makes our team look
very much less and less like a scrappy
innovative project.

For every new thing
that's been tested, you say, I don't want
to touch that next time. So the final 1% of
errors in our system,

I would say, also, without
proof that they were Poisson distributed in occurrence,
they could end a mission

at any minute. So if you wanted
to have any change, it would really
have to be something

that you were getting good
statistics on for failure. The next one was
buying versus building.

This is like a constant
ITE conversation. Should I build my
own email server? Or should I just pay
Gmail to do it for me?

So partners that
brought technology like Boston Dynamics
or Meshmerize,

they were very beneficial. But if we ended up going to
some outsourced industry for, like, saying, please
solve the problem for us.

We, actually, had a
couple of components that were like, we tried
using consultants for or even

like a small
businesses, we ended up just not being able
to integrate it.

And it's because if
we needed some change, we would have had to go back
to them, have them change it. Or we would have had to master
their system afterwards.

This is a real problem. So there's a bit
of a nuance there. I'll say, a foundation
for autonomy

is still definitely missing. Maybe, at this
point in the talk, you're already
familiar with this. And you believe me.

But industry is still
seeking a total solution. We have no really
well-established framework for getting to the
level of reliability

that I think is necessary. And even as recently
as last week with this DARPA racer
project, there's

this startup that
started out by professor at University of Washington
called Overland AI.

It's hoping to
solve the problem. I think that there's going to
be many startups like this that have to be trying to solve this
general foundation for autonomy

before we finally can see
it in many applications. And the last thing
that I'll mention,

which might be something that
the business folks among us might already really appreciate,
but I think was a news for us,

was personnel and project
management is sometimes, I would argue, maybe,
very frequently,

more important than the
deep tech innovation that you're thinking you're
bringing to the table. We had some really
deep tech innovations

we wanted to show off at
the DARPA SubT Challenge. And yet, the thing I think
that really stopped us

from being successful was
being able to have scientists and engineers with
project oversight that

felt like they were, actually,
empowered to make decisions, because they were there
having conversations

daily with the people that were
trying to solve deep problems. So I think that that's the last
thing that I'll mention there.

Moving away from this
pontification about what we learned, I think that there's
something to be said about,
what didn't we learn? And so there was this final--

the conclusion of
the final event, there was this PI roundtable. Here's the program
manager Tim Chang

asking all the PIs, which
part of this problem are Solved and many areas during
that roundtable were asserted

to have been solved that I think
I take explicit exception to. Obviously, I would agree
with some of the sentiments.

But I want to just zoom
out a little bit and say, the robot stands here.

So this-- let's see, if we
can get this video going. The robot stands here
for over two minutes.

It may be waiting
for human input. Maybe, it's calculating a plan. Maybe, it's trying to
resolve a perception issue,

like, calculating
a loop closure. Either way, it's
wasting precious time. And I don't think that
agility in this context

is solved in any
definition of the phrase. If we can have a robot sitting
in a spot for two minutes,

that's equivalent
to a human sitting in a spot for two minutes
trying to figure out what they should do next. I think that's problematic.

I don't think that we're
anywhere near human capability. This was the first place
team during the final run.

So I think there's something
to be said about that. I would say that environmental
disturbances aren't solved.

This is the second place
team, Data61 CSIRO. You can see a bunch
of graduate students.

Oh, no. They have to rebuild
that quadrotor overnight. It's not easy.

Now, DARPA did replace
that piece of paper afterwards, just so
that it was fair.

And I'm not going to only
claim the other teams had all the problems. We had plenty of problems.

Here's our robot standing
there for a while. And then trying to figure
out how it can move around.

What is it doing? This is just so frustrating
to see as a roboticist with an autonomy focus on it.

And then out of commission. Anything can happen. I think that there's
so many problems that

are still unsolved. I would go so far as to say,
anecdotes aren't the only thing that I can bring to
